014package org.jdbi.v3.core.statement;
015
016import java.sql.SQLException;
017import java.sql.Statement;
018import java.util.ArrayList;
019import java.util.List;
020
021import org.jdbi.v3.core.Handle;
022import org.slf4j.Logger;
023import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
024
025/**
026 * Represents a group of non-prepared statements to be sent to the RDMBS in one "request".
027 */
028public class Batch extends BaseStatement<Batch> {
029    private static final Logger LOG = LoggerFactory.getLogger(Batch.class);
030
031    private final List<String> parts = new ArrayList<>();
032
033    public Batch(Handle handle) {
034        super(handle);
035    }
036
037    /**
038     * Add a statement to the batch
039     *
040     * @param sql SQL to be added to the batch, possibly a named statement
041     * @return the same Batch statement
042     */
043    public Batch add(String sql) {
044        parts.add(sql);
045        return this;
046    }
047
048    /**
049     * Execute the batch and return the number of rows affected for each batch part.
050     * Note that some database drivers might return special values like {@link Statement#SUCCESS_NO_INFO}
051     * or {@link Statement#EXECUTE_FAILED}.
052     *
053     * @return the number of rows affected per batch part
054     * @see Statement#executeBatch()
055     */
056    public int[] execute() {
057        // short circuit empty batch
058        if (parts.isEmpty()) {
059            return new int[] {};
060        }
061
062        @SuppressWarnings("PMD.CloseResource")
063        Statement stmt;
064        try {
065            try {
066                stmt = getHandle().getStatementBuilder().create(getHandle().getConnection(), getContext());
067
068                addCleanable(stmt::close);
069                getConfig(SqlStatements.class).customize(stmt);
070            } catch (SQLException e) {
071                throw new UnableToCreateStatementException(e, getContext());
072            }
073
074            LOG.trace("Execute batch [");
075
076            try {
077                for (String part : parts) {
078                    final String sql = getConfig(SqlStatements.class).getTemplateEngine().render(part, getContext());
079                    LOG.trace(" {}", sql);
080                    stmt.addBatch(sql);
081                }
082            } catch (SQLException e) {
083                throw new UnableToExecuteStatementException("Unable to configure JDBC statement", e, getContext());
084            }
085
086            try {
087                return SqlLoggerUtil.wrap(stmt::executeBatch, getContext(), getConfig(SqlStatements.class).getSqlLogger());
088            } catch (SQLException e) {
089                throw new UnableToExecuteStatementException(mungeBatchException(e), getContext());
090            }
091        } finally {
092            close();
093        }
094    }
095
096    /**
097     * SQLExceptions thrown from batch executions have errors
098     * in a {@link SQLException#getNextException()} chain, which
099     * doesn't print out when you log them.  Convert them to be
100     * {@link Throwable#addSuppressed(Throwable)} exceptions,
101     * which do print out with common logging frameworks.
102     *
103     * @param e the exception
104     * @return the 'suppressed' munged exception change
105     */
106    static SQLException mungeBatchException(SQLException e) {
107        for (SQLException next = e.getNextException(); next != null; next = next.getNextException()) {
108            e.addSuppressed(next);
109        }
110        return e;
111    }
112}
